subject: Economics
title: Zimbabwe's Trillion-Dollar Note: When Zeros Mean Nothing
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Zimbabwe's Trillion-Dollar Note: When Zeros Mean Nothing.

hook.text: Zimbabwe printed a 100-trillion-dollar note in 2008. It couldn't buy a bus ticket. Monthly inflation hit 79.

buildup.text: Land reform collapsed agriculture. Government printed money to cover deficits. Prices rose by the hour.

discovery.text: Shops changed prices three times a day. Workers demanded payment in foreign currency or refused to show up.

twist.text: Zimbabwe abandoned its own currency entirely. The US dollar and South African rand became legal tender instead.

climax.text: A country can print infinite money. It cannot print infinite value. The two are completely different things.

punchline.text: Adding zeros to paper doesn't add value to an economy.

quiz.question: How did Zimbabwe resolve its hyperinflation crisis?
options: Abandoned its currency and adopted foreign currencies
